{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} [[File:MBTA commuter car headend.agr.jpg|thumb|[[MBTA]] commuter rail car with U.S. standard head-end power [[Jumper cable|electrical connection cables]]]] In [[rail transport]], '''head-end power''' ('''HEP'''), also known as '''electric train supply''' ('''ETS''') is the electrical power distribution system on a passenger train. The power source, usually a locomotive (or a generator car) at the front or 'head' of a train, provides the electricity used for heating, lighting, electrical and other 'hotel' needs. The maritime equivalent is [[hotel electric power]]. A successful attempt by the [[London, Brighton and South Coast Railway]] in October 1881 to light the passenger car between London and Brighton<ref name="jfl">{{cite book | last = JFL | title = Train lighting by electricity | publisher = Ben Johnson & Co. | year = 1914 | location = London and York | accessdate = 2013-03-17 | url =https://archive.org/details/trainlightingbye00jflouoft/ }}</ref> heralded the beginning of using electricity to light trains in the world.
==History==
Oil lamps were introduced in 1842 to light trains.<ref name="SimmonsEvans2003">{{cite book|author1=Jack Simmons|author2=A. K. B. Evans|author3=John V Gough|title=The Impact of the Railway on Society in Britain: Essays in Honour of Jack Simmons|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VVXjt4KZWL8C&pg=PA49|accessdate=17 March 2013|year=2003|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7546-0949-0|pages=49–}}</ref> Economics drove the [[Lancashire and Yorkshire Railway]] to replace oil with coal gas lighting in 1870, but a gas cylinder explosion on the train led them to abandon the experiment.<ref name="SimmonsEvans2003"/> Oil-gas lighting was introduced in late 1870. Electrical lighting was introduced in October 1881<ref name="jfl"/><ref name="SimmonsEvans2003"/> by using twelve [[Joseph Swan|Swan]] carbon filament incandescent lamps connected to an underslung battery of 32 [[Camille Alphonse Faure|Faure]] [[lead-acid]] rechargeable cells, suitable for about 6 hours lighting before being removed for recharging.<ref name="jfl"/>
The [[North British Railway]] in 1881 successfully generated electricity using a dynamo on the ''Brotherhood'' steam locomotive to provide electrical lighting in a train, a concept that was later called ''head-end power''. High steam consumption led to abandonment of the system. Three trains were started in 1883 by [[London, Brighton and South Coast Railway]] with electricity generated on board using a dynamo driven from one of the axles. This charged a lead-acid battery in the guard's van, and the guard operated and maintained the equipment. The system successfully provided electric lighting in the train.<ref name="jfl"/>
In 1887, steam-driven generators in the [[baggage car]]s<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stuart|first1=Charles W. T.|title=A Few Points in the History of Car Lighting|journal=Railway Electrical Engineer|date=May 1919|volume=10|issue=5|page=158|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3xQ6AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA158&lpg=PA158&dq=generator+florida+special+baggage+car&source=bl&ots=_kVRSIDzwt&sig=GGxXgvGW3Sj41zzKypz7XtAkMd0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=50b8U--ALcOryASAzIHABg&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=generator%20florida%20special%20baggage%20car&f=false|accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref> of the ''Florida Special'' and the ''Chicago Limited'' trains in the US supplied electric lighting to all the cars of the train by wiring them, to introduce the other form of head-end power.<ref>{{White-Passenger-1985}}</ref>
The oil-gas lighting provided a higher intensity of light compared to electric lighting and was more popularly used till September 1913, when an [[1913 Ais Gill rail accident|accident]] on the [[Midland Railway]] at [[Aisgill]] caused a large number of passenger deaths. This accident prompted railways to adopt electricity for lighting the trains.<ref name="jfl"/>
Throughout the remainder of the [[steam locomotive|age of steam]] and into the early diesel era, passenger cars were heated by low pressure [[saturated steam]] supplied by the locomotive, with the electricity for car lighting and [[HVAC|ventilation]] being derived from [[battery (electricity)|batteries]] charged by axle-driven [[electrical generator|generator]]s on each car, or from [[engine-generator]] sets mounted under the carbody. Starting in the 1930s, [[air conditioning]] became available on railcars, with the energy to run them being provided by mechanical [[power take off]]s from the axle, small dedicated engines or [[propane refrigerator|propane]].
The resulting separate systems of lighting power, steam heat, and engine-driven air conditioning, increased the maintenance workload as well as parts proliferation. Head-end power would allow for a single power source to handle all those functions, and more, for an entire train.
In the steam era, all cars in Finland and Russia had a wood or coal fired fireplace. Such a solution was considered a fire danger in most countries in Europe, but not in Russia.
==United Kingdom== Originally, trains hauled by a [[steam locomotive]] would be provided with a supply of steam from the locomotive for heating the carriages.<ref name="jfl"/> When [[diesel locomotive]]s and [[electric locomotives]] replaced steam, the steam heating was then supplied by a [[Steam generator (railroad)|steam-heat boiler]]. This was oil-fired (in diesel locomotives) or heated by an electric element (in electric locomotives). Oil-fired steam-heat boilers were unreliable. They caused more locomotive failures on any class to which they were fitted than any other system or component of the locomotive,{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}} and this was a major incentive to adopt a more reliable method of carriage heating.
At this time, lighting was powered by [[battery (electricity)|batteries]] which were charged by a [[electrical generator|dynamo]] underneath each carriage when the train was in motion, and [[buffet car]]s would use [[bottled gas]] for cooking and water heating.<ref name="jfl"/>
===Electric Train Heat (ETH) and Electric Train Supply (ETS)=== Later diesels and [[electric locomotive]]s were equipped with '''Electric Train Heating''' ('''ETH''') apparatus, which supplied electrical power to the carriages to run electric heating elements installed alongside the steam-heat apparatus, which was retained for use with older locomotives. Later carriage designs abolished the steam-heat apparatus, and made use of the ETH supply for heating, lighting, ventilation, [[air conditioning]], fans, sockets and kitchen equipment in the train. In recognition of this ETH was eventually renamed '''Electric Train Supply''' ('''ETS''').
Each coach has an index relating to the maximum consumption of electricity that it could use. The sum of all the indices must not exceed the index of the locomotive. One "ETH index unit" equals 5 kW; a locomotive with an ETH index of 95 can supply 475 kW of electrical power to the train.
==North America== The first advance over the old axle generator system was developed on the [[Boston and Maine Railroad]], which had placed a number of steam locomotives and passenger cars into dedicated commuter service in [[Boston]]. Due to the low average speeds and frequent stops characteristic of a commuter operation, the axle generators' output was insufficient to keep the batteries charged, resulting in passenger complaints about lighting and ventilation failures. In response, the railroad installed higher capacity generators on the locomotives assigned to these trains, and provided electrical connections to the cars. The cars used steam from the locomotive for heating.
Some early diesel streamliners took advantage of their fixed-consist construction to employ electrically-powered lighting, air conditioning, and heating. As the cars were not meant to mix with existing passenger stock, compatibility of these systems was not a concern. For example, the [[Nebraska Zephyr]] trainset has three diesel generator sets in the first car to power onboard equipment.
When diesel locomotives were introduced to passenger service, they were equipped with [[steam generator (railroad)|steam generator]]s to provide steam for car heating. However, the use of axle generators and batteries persisted for many years. This started to change in the late 1950s, during which time the [[Chicago and North Western Railway]] removed the steam generators from their [[EMD F7]] and [[EMD E8|E8]] locomotives in commuter service and installed [[diesel generator]] sets (see ''[[Peninsula 400]]''). This was a natural evolution, as their commuter trains were already receiving low-voltage, low-current power from the locomotives to assist axle generators in maintaining battery charge.
While many commuter fleets were quickly converted to HEP, long-distance trains continued to operate with steam heat and battery-powered electrical systems. This gradually changed following the transfer of intercity passenger rail service to [[Amtrak]] and [[Via Rail]], ultimately resulting in full adoption of HEP in the US and Canada and the discontinuation of the old systems.
Following its formation in 1971, Amtrak's initial locomotive purchase was the [[Electro-Motive Diesel|Electro-Motive]] (EMD) [[EMD SDP40F|SDP40F]], an adaptation of the widely used [[EMD SD40-2|SD40-2]] 3000 horsepower freight locomotive, fitted with a passenger style carbody and steam generating capability. The SDP40F permitted the use of modern motive power in conjunction with the old steam-heated passenger cars acquired from predecessor railroads, allowing Amtrak time to procure purpose-built cars and locomotives.
In 1975, Amtrak started to take delivery of the all-electric [[Amfleet]] car, hauled by [[General Electric]] (GE) [[GE P30CH|P30CH]] and [[GE E60|E60CH]] locomotives, later augmented by EMD [[EMD F40PH|F40PH]] and [[EMD AEM-7|AEM7]] locomotives, all of which were equipped to furnish HEP. Five Amtrak E8s were rebuilt with HEP generators for this purpose. In addition, 15 baggage cars were converted to HEP generator cars to allow the hauling of Amfleet by non-HEP motive power (such as [[PRR GG1|GG1s]] substituting for unreliable [[Budd Metroliner|Metroliner EMUs]]). Following the introduction of the Amfleet, the (all-electric) [[Superliner (railcar)|Superliner]] railcar was placed into operation on long-distance western routes. Amtrak subsequently converted a portion of the steam-heated fleet to all-electric operation using HEP, and retired the remaining unconverted cars by the mid-1980s.<ref>{{cite news | first = Bob | last = Johnson | title = Head-end power | date = 1 May 2006 | url = http://trn.trains.com/railroads/abcs-of-railroading/2006/05/head-end-power | work = ABCs of Railroading | accessdate = 9 November 2014}}</ref>
==Engine== The HEP generator can be driven by either a separate engine mounted in the locomotive or generator car, or by the locomotive's [[prime mover (locomotive)|prime mover]].
===Separate engines=== {{main|Auxiliary power unit}} Genset-supplied HEP is usually through an auxiliary diesel unit that is independent from the main propulsion (prime mover) engine. Such [[Diesel generator|engine/generator]] sets are generally installed in a compartment in the rear of the locomotive. Both the prime mover and the HEP genset share fuel supplies.
Smaller under-car engine/generator sets for providing electricity on short trains are also manufactured.
===Locomotive prime mover=== In many applications, the locomotive's prime mover provides both propulsion and head-end power. If the HEP generator is driven by the engine then it must run at a constant speed ([[revolutions per minute|RPM]]) to maintain the required 50 Hz or 60 Hz AC line [[frequency]]. An engineer will not have to keep the throttle in a higher run position, as the onboard electronics control the speed of the engine to maintain the set frequency.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://trn.trains.com/railroads/abcs-of-railroading/2006/05/head-end-power| publisher=''Kalmbach Publishing Co'' | title=Head-end power - TRAINS magazine| date=2006-05-01| accessdate=9 November 2014 }}</ref>
More recently, locomotives have adopted the use of a static inverter, powered from the traction generator, which allows the prime mover to have a larger RPM range.
When derived from the prime mover, HEP is generated at the expense of traction power. For example, the [[General Electric]] {{Convert|3200|hp|MW|lk=in|abbr=on}} [[GE Genesis#P32AC-DM|P32]] and {{Convert|4000|hp|MW|abbr=on}} [[GE Genesis#P42DC|P40]] locomotives are derated to {{Convert|2900|and|3650|hp|MW|abbr=on}}, respectively, when supplying HEP. The [[Fairbanks-Morse]] [[FM P-12-42|P-12-42]] was one of the first HEP equipped locomotives to have its prime mover configured to run at a constant speed, with traction generator output regulated solely by varying excitation voltage.
One of the first tests of HEP powered by an EMD locomotive's prime mover was in 1969, on [[Milwaukee Road]] [[EMD E9]] #33C, which was converted to have a constant speed rear engine.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://sbcglobalpwp.att.net/w/i/willvdv/ros7milw.html| title=Milwaukee Road Commuter Locomotives }}{{dead link|date=January 2011}}</ref>
==Electrical loading== HEP power supplies the lighting, [[HVAC]], dining car kitchen and battery charging loads. Individual car electrical loading ranges from 20 kW for a typical car to more than 150 kW for a [[Dome car]] with kitchen and dining area, such as Princess Tours [[Ultra Dome]] cars operating in [[Alaska]]. <ref name="Northwest Rail">{{cite web| url=http://www.nwrail.com/HEP_config.html| title=HEP Trainline Configurations in North America| publisher=''Northwest Rail''| accessdate=2011-01-29 }}</ref>
==Voltage== [[File:Electric power supply cable of YZ25T 357470 (20151229085331).jpg|thumb|Connection cables between two China Railways 25T coaches]] ===North America=== Because of train lengths and the high power requirements in [[North America]], HEP is supplied as [[Three-phase electric power|three-phase]] AC at 480 [[Volt|V]] (standard in the US and Canada), 575 V, or 600 V. [[Transformer]]s are fitted in each car for reduction to lower voltages.<ref name="Northwest Rail"/>
===United Kingdom=== In the UK, ETS is supplied at 800 V to 1000 V AC/DC two pole (400 or 600 A), 1500 V AC two pole (800 A) or at 415 V 3 phase on the [[InterCity 125|HST]]. On the former Southern Region, Mk I carriages were wired for a 750 V DC supply. This corresponds to line voltage on the Third Rail network. Class 73 Locomotives simply supply this line voltage direct to the ETS jumpers, whilst Class 33 Diesel Electric Locomotives have a separate engine driven Train Heating Generator which supplies 750 V DC to the train heating connections.
===Ireland=== In Ireland, HEP is provided at European/IEC standard 230/400 V 50 Hz (originally 220/380 V 50 Hz.) This is to the same specification as the power systems used in Irish and EU domestic and commercial buildings and industry.
On the Cork-Dublin CAF MK4 sets, this is provided by two generators, located in the [[driving trailer]] van and on the push-pull Enterprise sets, this is provided by generators in a dedicated tailing van. Irish DMU trains, which make up the majority of the fleet, use small generators located under each coach.
Historically, HEP and, in older vehicles, steam heating was provided by trailing generator vans containing generators and [[steam generator (railroad)|steam boiler]]s. These were normally located on the rear of train sets. The Enterprise Dublin-Belfast train sets initially used HEP from [[IE 201 Class|GM 201 diesel-electric locomotive]]s, but due reliability issues and excessive wear on the locomotives systems, generator vans (sourced from retired Irish Rail MK3 sets and adapted for push-pull use) were added.
===Russia=== Russian cars use electric heating with either 3 kV DC voltage on DC lines or 3 kV AC voltage on AC lines provided by locomotive's main transformer. Newer cars are mostly made by Western European manufacturers and are equipped similarly to RIC cars.
===Europe (RIC cars, except Russia and UK)=== [[International Coach Regulations|RIC]] cars must be able to be supplied at all the following four voltages: 1,000 V AC {{frac|16|2|3}} Hz, 1,500 V AC 50 Hz, 1,500 V DC and 3,000 V DC. The first one is used in Austria, Germany, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland, where the {{15 kV AC}} [[Overhead lines|catenary system]] is used (some parking place sockets use 1,000 V AC 50 Hz). The second one (1.5 kV AC) is used in countries which use {{25 kV 50 Hz}} catenary system (Croatia, Denmark, Finland, Hungary, Serbia and UK, and some lines in France, Italy and Russia). In both cases, the proper voltage is provided by the locomotive's main transformer or an AC alternator in diesel locomotives. In countries using DC power (either 1.5 kV or 3 kV DC), the voltage collected by the pantograph is supplied directly to the cars. (Belgium, Poland and Spain, and some lines in Russia and Italy use 3 kV, and the Netherlands, and some lines in France use 1.5 kV; see more detailed information in the ''[[List of railway electrification systems]]'' article.)
Older European cars used high voltage (or steam – supplied by steam locomotive (some diesels and electrics also had steam boilers fitted), there were also [[Steam generator (railroad)|steam generator cars]] in use and some cars were fitted with coal- or oil-fired boiler) only for heating, while light, fans and other low-current supply (e.g. shaver sockets in bathrooms) power was provided by axle-driven generator. Today, with the developments in solid state electronics (thyristors and IGBTs), most cars have switching power supplies which take any RIC voltage (1.0 – 3.0 kV DC or {{frac|16|2|3}}/50 Hz) and can supply all the needed lower voltages. Low voltages differ depending on manufacturers, but typical values are: * 12 V – 48 V DC for on-board electronics (supplied from chemical battery when HEP disabled) * 24 V – 110 V DC for feeding fluorescent lamps' electronic ballasts and for ventilation fans (supplied from chemical battery when HEP disabled) * Single phase 230 V AC for passenger sockets, refrigerators etc. (sometimes supplied from chemical battery, as above) * Three phase 400 V AC for air conditioning compressor, heating, ventilation fans (air cond. is nowadays not supplied from chemical battery due to power consumption)
Electric heating was typically supplied from high-voltage HEP line, but the unusual voltages are not common on the market and the equipment is expensive.
A standard RIC-compliant HV heater has six resistors which are being switched accordingly to voltage: 6 in [[Series and parallel circuits#Series circuits|series]] (3 kV DC), 2 × 3 in series (1.5 kV AC or DC) or 3 × 2 in series (1 kV AC). The selection and switching of a proper configuration is automatic for the sake of safety. Passengers can only operate [[thermostat]].
===China=== [[File:KD25K 998717@BJX (20150118131543).JPG|thumb|A KD<sub>25K</sub> [[Head end power car|generator car]] in a passenger train]] In China, HEP is supplied in two forms.
On all 25A/G cars built before 2005, rebuilt and air-conditioned 22/25B cars, most 25K cars, and most BSP-built 25T cars, HEP is supplied at three-phase 380 V AC by generator cars (originally classified as TZ cars, later reclassified to KD), a small number of DF11G diesel locomotives, and very limited number of retrofitted [[China Railways SS9|SS9]] electrics. Cars with diesel generator sets (factory-built RZ/RW/CA22/23/25B cars, some rebuilt YZ/YW22/23/25B cars, most German-built 24 cars, and very limited number of 25G/K/T cars for special use) also supply their own power in this form. It's possible to route AC electricity from a car with diesel generator set to a neighboring normal HEP car, although both cars can't run their air conditioning or heat on full load in this situation. Those diesel-powered cars can also run on HEP from elsewhere, without using their own diesel. Although considered inefficient and obsolete, mainly because the generator car 'wastes' traction power, staff, and fuel (if running on electrified lines), new cars using AC HEP are still in production, along with new generator cars/sets, mostly for use in areas without electrification, considering that the vast majority of China Railways' engines that are capable of supplying HEP are electric locomotives.
On most newer 25G cars and 25/19T cars, power is supplied at 600 V DC by electric locos such as SS7C, SS7D, SS7E, [[China Railways SS8|SS8]], [[China Railways SS9|SS9]], [[China Railways HXD1D|HXD1D]], [[China Railways HXD3C|HXD3C]], [[China Railways HXD3D|HXD3D]], and some [[China Railways DF11G|DF11G]] diesels (No.0041, 0042, 0047, 0048, 0053-0056, 0101-0218). Small number of special generator cars (QZ-KD25T) designated for use on the high-altitude [[Qinghai–Tibet Railway]] also supply power at 600 V DC. With new DC-equipped engines and cars entering service rapidly, as well as ageing and retirement of older equipments using AC, DC HEP has become the more prominent form of power supply of China Railways.
Very limited number of cars, mostly 25Ts, can run on both forms of HEP.
==Alternatives== [[File:IE DVT 1.JPG|thumb|right|256px|CAF DVT with twin HEP generator sets at Colbert Station, Limerick, Republic of Ireland in 2006]] Although most locomotive-hauled trains take power directly from the locomotive, there have been examples (mainly in continental [[Europe]]) where restaurant cars could take power directly from the [[Overhead line|overhead wires]] while the train is standing and not connected to head-end power. For example, the German restaurant cars WRmz 135 (1969), WRbumz 139 (1975) and ARmz 211 (1971) were all equipped with [[Pantograph (transport)|pantographs]].
Some Finnish dining/catering cars have a built-in diesel-generator set that is used even when a locomotive-supplied power is available.
When the State of Connecticut began the [[Shore Line East]] service, they were using, in many cases, new passenger cars with old freight diesels which were not able to supply HEP, so some of the coaches were delivered with an HEP generator installed. With the acquisition of locomotives with HEP these have since been removed.
Where a passenger train must be hauled by a locomotive with no HEP supply (or an incompatible HEP supply) a separate generator van may be used <ref>{{cite web| url=http://philtpics.fotopic.net/p39561132.html| title=a generator van converted from a Mk.1 BG| publisher=''Phil Trotter''| quote=During the 1980s, during low HST power car availability, a generator van converted from a Mk.1 BG was used to provide three-phase power to HST rakes so that they could be locomotive hauled. ADB975325 (later renumbered 6310) is seen at Bristol Temple Meads on 4th October 1980| date=2007-03-19| accessdate=2011-01-29}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> such as on the [[Amtrak Cascades]] train or [[Iarnród Éireann]]'s [[Mark 4 (Iarnród Éireann)#Mark 4 DVT|CAF Mark 4 Driving Van Trailer]] (with twin MAN 2846 LE 202 (320 kW) / Letag (330 kVA) engine / generator sets, assembled by GESAN). [[KiwiRail]] (New Zealand) use [[NZR FM guards van|AG class]] luggage-generator vans for their [[Tranz Scenic]] passenger services; [[Tranz Metro]] on the Wairarapa line use [[New Zealand British Rail Mark 2 carriage#SW class|SWG class]] passenger carriages with part of the interior adapted to house a generator. The [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus]] train used at least one custom-built power car that supplied HEP to its passenger coaches to avoid reliance upon host railway locomotives hauling the train.
In UK and Sweden the high-speed trains IC125 and X2000 have 50 Hz 3-phase power bus.

{{Gnosticism}} The '''''Hypostasis of the Archons''''' or '''''The Reality of the Rulers''''' is an [[exegesis]] on the ''[[Book of Genesis]]'' 1–6 and expresses [[Gnostic]] mythology of the divine creators of the cosmos and humanity.{{sfn|Meyer|Robinson|1977|p=152}} == Text's origin and content == The text was found among those included in The [[Nag Hammadi Library]], in [[Nag Hammadi Codex II|CG II]], in 1945. It is tentatively dated in the third century CE{{sfn|Meyer|Robinson|1977|p=152}}{{sfn|Mills|Bullard|1990|p=398}} and is thought to originate from a transitional period in Gnosticism when it was converting from a purely mythological state into a philosophical phase. The beginning and conclusion to the document are Christian Gnostic, but the rest of the material is a mythological narrative regarding the origin and nature of the archontic powers peopling the heavens between Earth and the [[Ogdoad (Gnosticism)|Ogdoad]], and how the destiny of man is affected by these primeval happenings.Bullard in Robinson 162; Bullard 3 The work is presented as a learned treatise in which a teacher addresses a topic suggested by the dedicatee of the work. The treatise begins with a fragment of [[cosmogony]], which leads to a revisionistic "true history" of the events in the Genesis creation story, reflecting Gnostic distrust of the material world and the demiurge that created it. Within this narrative there is an "angelic revelation dialogue" where an angel repeats and elaborates the author's fragment of cosmogonic myth in much broader scope, concluding with historical prediction of the coming of the savior and the end of days.Layton (1995) 65 Although the [[Etymology|etymologies]] and puns on Semitic names suggest the author's close contact with [[Judaism|Jewish]] legends and interpretive traditions as well as knowledge of [[Greek mythology]] and [[Hellenistic_period|Hellenistic]] [[Hellenistic_religion|cult]] practices, the myth is, according to [[Bentley Layton]] purposefully anti-Judaic (coining its traditional early rabbinic form, although no reason to placard it as anti-semittic).Layton (1995) 65 In addition, arguably, the work contains no Christian anti-Gnostic characteristics.Layton (1995) 65 As the original Greek text has not been discovered, the only known version is the Coptic translation from Nag Hammadi.Layton (1995) 67 ==Mythic characters== ''The Parent of the Entirety'': The invisible virgin spirit
''Incorruptibility''
''The Child'': Presides over the entirety
''The Four Luminaries'': [[Eleleth]] and three others
''The True Human Being''
''The Undominated Race''
''[[Wisdom]]'': [[Sophia (gnosticism)|Sophia]] or [[Pistis Sophia]]
''Zoe ([[Life]])'': daughter of Sophia
''[[Yaldabaoth]]'': The chief ruler also called [[Yaldabaoth#Yaldabaoth|Sakla]] and [[Samael]]
''[[Sabaoth]]'': One of Yaldabaoth's first seven offspring
''[[Adam]]'': The first human being
''[[Eve]]'': Adam's wife and counterpart
''[[Cain]]'': Eve's son begotten by the rulers
''[[Abel]]'': Eve's son begotten by Adam
''[[Seth]]'': a son through god
''[[Norea]]'': Eve's daughterLayton (1995) 66 == Notes == ==References== *Bullard, Roger A. "The Hypostasis of the Archons." Berlin: De Gruyter, 1970. *Bullard, Roger A. Introduction to “The Hypostasis of the Archons”. In ''The Nag Hammadi Library in English'', Revised Edition. Edited by James M. Robinson, 161–162. San Francisco: Harper and Row, 1988. *Fallon, Francis T. "The Enthronement of Sabaoth: Jewish Elements in Gnostic Creation Myths". Leiden: Brill, 1978. *Fallon, Francis T. "The Gnostics: The Undominated Race". Novum Testamentum 21.3 (1979): 271–88. *Gilhus, Ingvild Sælid. "The Nature of the Archons: A Study in the Soteriology of a Gnostic Treatise from Nag Hammadi (CGII, 4)". Wiesbaden: Otto Harrassowitz, 1985. *[[Karen Leigh King|King, Karen L]]. “Ridicule and Rape, Rule and Rebellion: The Hypostasis of the Archons”. In ''Gnosticism and the Early Christian World: In Honor of James M. Robinson''. Edited by James E. Goehring et al., Sonoma, California:Polebridge, 1990. *Layton, Bentley. ''The Gnostic Scriptures: A New Translation with Annotations and Introductions''. New York: Doubleday, 1995; 1987. *[[Bentley Layton|Layton, Bentley]]. “The Hypostasis of the Archons”. [[Harvard Theological Review]] 67 (1974):351–425. *Layton, Bentley. “The Hypostasis of the Archons (Conclusion)”. Harvard Theological Review 69 (1976):31–101. *McGuire, Anne. "Virginity and Subversion: Norea Against the Powers in ''The Hypostasis of the Archons''". In ''Images of the Feminine in Gnosticism''. Edited by Karen L. King, 239–258. Philadelphia: Fortress Press, 1988. *{{cite book|last1=Meyer|first1=Marvin W.|last2=Robinson|first2=James MacConkey|title=The Nag Hammadi Library in English|date=1977|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004054349|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1bU3AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA152&dq=Hypostasis+of+the+Archons&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiqnf6o4vrMAhULOVIKHXi4BrUQ6AEIRjAI#v=onepage&q=Hypostasis%20of%20the%20Archons&f=false|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last1=Mills|first1=Watson E.|last2=Bullard|first2=Roger Aubrey|title=Mercer Dictionary of the Bible|date=1990|publisher=Mercer University Press|isbn=9780865543737|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=goq0VWw9rGIC&pg=PA398&dq=Hypostasis+of+the+Archons&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiCztHL6PrMAhWJ6YMKHWIpC7o4ChDoAQgqMAM#v=onepage&q=Hypostasis%20of%20the%20Archons&f=false|ref=harv}} == External links == ;Online texts * [http://www.gnosis.org/naghamm/hypostas.html Selection from James M. Robinson, ed., The Nag Hammadi Library, Translated by Bentley Layton] * [https://ww3.haverford.edu/religion/courses/222a/hyparchons.htm Translated by Anne McGuire] {{The Nag Hammadi Codices |state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hypostasis Of The Archons}} [[Category:Biblical exegesis]] [[Category:Gnosticism]] [[Category:Early Christianity and Gnosticism]]

|website = [http://www.ligo.org/ www.ligo.org] }} The '''LIGO Scientific Collaboration''' ('''LSC''') is a scientific collaboration of international physics institutes and research groups dedicated to the search for [[gravitational waves]]. ==History== The LSC was established in 1997, under the leadership of [[Barry Barish]].{{cite book |last= Committee on Setting Priorities for NSF-Sponsored Large Research Facility Projects, Committee on Science, Engineering, and Public Policy, Policy and Global Affairs, Board on Physics and Astronomy, Division on Engineering and Physical Sciences, National Research Council. |date= 2004|title= Setting Priorities for Large Research Facility Projects Supported by the National Science Foundation |publisher= [[National Academies Press]] |pages= 129–136 |isbn=}} Its mission is to ensure equal scientific opportunity for individual participants and institutions by organizing research, publications, and all other scientific activities, and it includes scientists from both LIGO Laboratory and collaborating institutions. Barish appointed [[Rainer Weiss]] as the first spokesperson. LSC members have access to the US-based [[Advanced LIGO]] [[gravitational wave detector|detectors]] in [[LIGO Hanford Observatory|Hanford, Washington]] and in [[LIGO Livingston Observatory|Livingston, Louisiana]], as well as the [[GEO 600]] detector in [[Sarstedt]], Germany. Under an agreement with the [[European Gravitational Observatory]] (EGO), LSC members also have access to data from the [[Virgo interferometer|Virgo detector]] in [[Pisa]], Italy. While the LSC and the Virgo Collaboration are separate organizations, they cooperate closely and are referred to collectively as "LVC".{{cite web |url=https://dcc.ligo.org/public/0110/M1300550/011/LVC_MOUcallAndSummary.pdf |title=Open call for partnership for the EM identification and follow-up of GW candidate events |authors=Gabriela González, Fulvio Ricci, LIGO Scientific Collaboration, Virgo Collaboration |format=PDF |date=2015-12-06 |access-date=25 May 2016}} The current LSC Spokesperson is [[David Shoemaker]] from [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]]. The Executive Director of the LIGO Laboratory is [[David Reitze]] from the [[University of Florida]]. On 11 February 2016, the LIGO and Virgo collaborations{{efn|The 11 February 2016 announcement team were [[Kip Thorne]], [[David Reitze]], [[Gabriela González]], and [[Rainer Weiss]].}} announced that they succeeded in making the first direct [[Gravitational-wave astronomy|gravitational wave observation]] on 14 September 2015.{{Cite news|title = Gravitational Waves Exist: The Inside Story of How Scientists Finally Found Them| url = http://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/gravitational-waves-exist-heres-how-scientists-finally-found-them|newspaper = [[The New Yorker]]|access-date = 2016-02-11|issn = 0028-792X|first = Nicola|last = Twilley}}{{cite journal |author=Abbott, B.P. |title=Observation of Gravitational Waves from a Binary Black Hole Merger |url=http://journals.aps.org/prl/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevLett.116.061102 |journal=[[Phys. Rev. Lett.]] |volume=116 |pages=061102 |year=2016 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.116.061102 |display-authors=etal |pmid=26918975|arxiv=1602.03837 |bibcode=2016PhRvL.116f1102A }}{{cite news |last=Naeye |first=Robert |url=http://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/gravitational-wave-detection-heralds-new-era-of-science-0211201644/ |title=Gravitational Wave Detection Heralds New Era of Science |work=[[Sky and Telescope]] |date=11 February 2016 |accessdate=11 February 2016 }}{{cite journal |title=Einstein's gravitational waves found at last |journal=Nature News|url=http://www.nature.com/news/einstein-s-gravitational-waves-found-at-last-1.19361 |date=11 February 2016 |last=Castelvecchi |first=Davide |last2=Witze |first2=Alexandra |doi=10.1038/nature.2016.19361 |accessdate=11 February 2016 }} In 2016, Barish received the [[Enrico Fermi Prize]] "for his fundamental contributions to the formation of the LIGO and LIGO-Virgo scientific collaborations and for his role in addressing challenging technological and scientific aspects whose solution led to the first detection of gravitational waves".{{cite web|title=2016 Enrico '''''Landmark Columbus''''' is an organization in [[Columbus, Indiana]], United States, that is dedicated to caring for and celebrating the world-renowned [[cultural heritage]] of Columbus, a city which is home to seven of the forty three [[List of National Historic Landmarks in Indiana|National Historic Landmarks in Indiana]]. It was started as a program of Heritage Fund – The Community Foundation of Bartholomew County in 2015,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sisson|first1=Patrick|title=Columbus, Indiana, a Modernist Mecca, Updates Historic Preservation Efforts|url=http://www.curbed.com/2016/2/4/10941332/columbus-indiana-architecture-midcentury-modern|accessdate=14 May 2016|work=Curbed|date=4 February 2016}}</ref> and has been recognized for leading an innovative way to care for heritage without a protective law<ref>{{cite news |last1=Connors |first1=Will |title=Indiana Town Preserves Its Historic Architecture, Without a Protective Law |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/indiana-town-preserves-its-historic-architecture-without-a-protective-law-1491816606 |accessdate=21 June 2018 |work=Wall Street Journal |date=10 April 2017}}</ref> and making a positive impact in the community.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reports|first1=Staff|title=Group makes big impact with city’s heritage|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2015/11/18/group_makes_big_impact_with_citys_heritage/|accessdate=14 May 2016|work=The Republic|date=18 November 2015}}</ref> In 2016 it became a "Friends Organization" of Docomomo US<ref>{{cite web|title=A New Year and a New Organization in Columbus, Indiana {{!}} docomomo united states|url=http://docomomo-us.org/news/a_new_year_and_a_new_organization_columbus_indiana|website=docomomo-us.org|accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref> and remains a partner of the Indiana Modern committee of [[Indiana Landmarks]].
==History== The effort to start Landmark Columbus began in 2013 when the Columbus Redevelopment Commission began looking at new ways to research and examine<ref>{{cite news|title=Columbus taps conservator to preserve architecture|url=http://www.wdrb.com/story/22423226/columbus-taps-conservator-to-preserve-architecture|accessdate=14 May 2016|work=www.wdrb.com}}</ref> the current state for the design heritage in the Columbus Arts and Entertainment District.<ref name="AIC">{{cite journal|last1=McCoy|first1=Richard|title=The Columbus Challenge|journal=Objects Speciality Group Postprints|date=2014|volume=21|pages=363-377|url=http://resources.conservation-us.org/osg-postprints/wp-content/uploads/sites/8/2015/03/osg021-17.pdf|accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref> The start of this project came at a time when some of the modern works of [[architecture]] had begun to age and show signs of transition.<ref>{{cite web|title=Notes on Columbus, Indiana {{!}} docomomo united states|url=http://www.docomomo-us.org/news/notes_columbus_indiana|website=www.docomomo-us.org|accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref>
The effort officially launched as "Landmark Columbus" in 2015 as a program of Heritage Fund, and began producing events in the community.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McClure|first1=Julie|title=MONUMENTAL TASK|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2015/11/06/monumental_task|work=The Republic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Columbus Update: Civic Inspiration at the Right Scale {{!}} docomomo united states|url=http://docomomo-us.org/news/columbus_update_civic_inspiration_right_scale|website=docomomo-us.org|accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Karaim|first1=Reed|title=Is Columbus's Modernist Legacy at Risk?|url=http://www.architectmagazine.com/design/is-columbuss-modernist-legacy-at-risk_o|accessdate=23 July 2016|date=1 June 2016}}</ref> The effort has been seen as a way to preserve the design legacy of the town without relying on traditional historic preservation ordinances.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ross|first1=Michael Franklin|title=Saving the Columbus Occupational Health Association|url=http://archpaper.com/2016/08/columbus-occupational-health-association/#gallery-0-slide-1|accessdate=20 August 2016|work=Archpaper.com|date=19 August 2016}}</ref>
==Programs and advocacy projects== [[File:2015 Columbus Conversation - Davis, Prudon, and Joyner 11.jpg|thumb|Landmark Columbus' 2015 Columbus Conversation in the chapel at [[First Christian Church (Columbus, Indiana)|First Christian Church]]]] Landmark Columbus produces a number of ongoing programs and projects in an effort to care for the design heritage, most of which are created by an Advocacy and Education Committee.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McClure|first1=Julie|title=MONUMENTAL TASK|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2015/11/06/monumental_task|work=The Republic}}</ref> The organization is active in the community in various ways,<ref>{{cite news|title=Winter Magic, Spring Phoenix, and Columbus All Year|url=http://www.wfyi.org/programs/the-art-of-the-matter/radio/winter-magic-spring-phoenix-and-columbus-all-year|accessdate=30 July 2016|work=WFYI Public Media|date=14 January 2016}}</ref> including nominating the [[Irwin Conference Center]] <ref>{{cite web|title=A Modern landmark finds a new use|url=http://www.hiddengemsindiana.org/2015/01/irwin-conference-center-columbus.html|website=Hidden Gems Indiana}}</ref> for a Docomomo US National Citation of Merit in 2014 for the [[National Historic Landmark]] building designed by [[Eero Saarinen]], which was restored through an adaptive reuse project by [[Cummins]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Citation of Merit - Cummins Irwin Conference Center & Office Buildings {{!}} docomomo united states|url=http://docomomo-us.org/citation_merit_cummins_irwin_conference_center_office_buildings|website=docomomo-us.org|accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref> Columbus historians David Sechrest and Ricky Berkey have been involved with the organization from the beginning, helping to create projects around both the early and modern history of the community.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McClure|first1=Julie|title=MONUMENTAL TASK|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2015/11/06/monumental_task|work=The Republic}}</ref>
===Friends of First Christian Church Architecture=== Friends of First Christian Church Architecture (FFCCA) is a collaborative effort with a mission to "is to preserve the architecture and design elements of FCC, a National Historic Landmark designed by Eliel & Eero Saarinen in 1942."<ref>{{cite web|title=Purpose|url=http://www.fccoc.org/building.php|website=www.fccoc.org|publisher=Friends of First Christian Church|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref> The project was launched in January 2017 as a partnership with First Christian Church, Heritage Fund, Landmark Columbus, and Indiana Landmarks.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sisson|first1=Patrick|title=Saving the country’s first modern church, and a Columbus architecture landmark|url=http://www.curbed.com/2017/2/2/14485452/eero-eliel-saarinen-first-christian-church-columbus-indiana|accessdate=2 February 2017|work=Curbed|date=2 February 2017}}</ref> The first project for FFCCA was to help save the sanctuary skylight,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blair|first1=Brian|title=First (Christian) things first: New group forms to protect city’s original Modernist building|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2017/01/24/first_christian_things_first/|accessdate=2 February 2017|work=The Republic|date=23 January 2017}}</ref> which leaked for years and caused damage.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Clark|first1=John|title=First Christian Church in need of help maintaining landmark {{!}} 1010 WCSI|url=http://1010wcsi.com/first-christian-church-in-need-of-help-maintaining-landmark/|accessdate=2 February 2017|work=1010wcsi.com|date=25 January 2017}}</ref> In August of 2018 FFCCA had raised enough resources from the congregation and throughout the community to have the skylight fully restored.<ref>{{cite news |last1=McClure |first1=Julie |title=Architectural integrity: First Christian Church skylight repair retains defining characteristic |url=http://www.therepublic.com/2018/08/08/architectural_integrity_first_christian_church_skylight_repair_retains_defining_characteristic/ |accessdate=8 August 2018 |work=The Republic}}</ref> Fundraising for the restoration of the skylight was a collaborative effort, and included contributions from the Church congregation, Kenny Glass, Inc., and the Columbus Area Visitors Center.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Reports |first1=Staff |title=Church’s skylight project highlights successful collaboration |url=http://www.therepublic.com/2018/08/24/churchs_skylight_project_highlights_successful_collaboration/ |accessdate=28 August 2018 |work=The Republic |date=23 August 2018}}</ref>
===Columbus Conversations=== Columbus Conversation is an annual symposium held to address a pressing need in the community related to Columbus' design heritage. The series began in 2014 and featured Theodore Prudon's keynote presentation "Modern Architecture as Heritage,"<ref>{{cite web|title=2014 Columbus Conversation|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AWArV-gUd2c|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=15 May 2016|date=14 May 2016}}</ref> and included lectures by Marsh Davis, from [[Indiana Landmarks]]; Louis Joyner, a Columbus-based architect; Richard McCoy; and a conversation moderated by Harry McCawley. <ref>{{cite news|last1=Elig|first1=Jenny|title=Preserving architecture taking center stage|work=The Republic|date=13 May 2014}}</ref>
The 2015 Columbus Conversation featured a panel discussion by Jeff Baker, the last president of Preserve to Enjoy, Inc.; Tricia Gilson from the Columbus Indiana Architectural Archives; Flora Chou, board member of Docomomo US; and Theodore Prudon, board president of Docomomo US.<ref>{{cite web|title=2015 Columbus Conversation by Landmark Columbus|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f2yt26zsCOc|website=YouTube|accessdate=14 May 2016|date=10 November 2015}}</ref> This moderated discussion defined ways that Landmark Columbus could raise awareness about caring for the areas design heritage and begin growing a constituency that actively helps in the cause.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McClure|first1=Julie|title=Landmark group invites residents for a chat about historic preservation|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2015/10/23/landmark_group_invites_residents_for_a_chat_about_historic_preservation/|website=The Republic|accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref>
===Chaotic Tuesdays=== [[File:2015 Chaotic Tuesday.jpg|thumb|left|A "Chaotic Tuesday" inside the Commons]] In celebration of [[Jean Tinguely]]'s masterwork, ''[[Chaos 1]]'', located inside the Commons, Landmark Columbus started "Chaotic Tuesdays" as a free community event during which everyone could see the [[kinetic art]]work operate during the evening.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blair|first1=Brian|title=Returning to a state of ‘Chaos’|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2015/02/22/returning_to_a_state_of_chaos/|accessdate=14 May 2016|work=The Republic}}</ref> The idea for the event came from the director of [[Museum Tinguely]], Roland Wetzel, when he visited in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Talking Chaos with Roland Wetzel|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T16pS4n3_Fs|website=YouTube|publisher=Landmark Columbus|accessdate=15 May 2016|date=15 May 2016}}</ref> The event happens on the fourth Tuesday of every month and has grown to be a partnership between many in the community and led by the Columbus Area Arts Council. Professors from Ivy Tech bring drawing materials for the community and provide lessons on how to draw the artwork, which Tinguely himself did many times; his drawings of ''Chaos 1'' are in collections around the world.
===Landscape architecture cleanups=== [[File:2015 North Christian Church Clean Up.jpg|thumb|2015 North Christian Church Landscape Clean Up]] Landmark Columbus has organized a number of community efforts to help clean and maintain the landscape at [[North Christian Church]], which was designed by [[Dan Kiley]] and is one of seven National Historic Landmarks in the city. Cleanups have addressed issues caused by storms and ongoing maintenance, including the dormant pruning of the many [[magnolia]]s that surround the church. <ref>{{cite news|last1=Blair|first1=Brian|title=Helping ‘a beacon’ shine on|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2016/01/16/helping_a_beacon_shine_on/|work=The Republic}}</ref>
===Yearly bicycle rides=== Landmark Columbus started a yearly bicycle tour in May that coincides with National Preservation Month and [[National Bike Month]]. * The 2015 "Olde Tyme Architectural Bicycle Ride" featured a tour of late 19th and early 20th century architecture and landscapes near downtown.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Clark|first1=John|title=Health advocates plan local bike month activities|url=http://1010wcsi.com/health-advocates-plan-local-bike-month-activities/|accessdate=15 May 2016|work=1010 WCSI}}</ref> * The 2016 "Mad Men Bike Ride" featured many works of modern architecture, including stops at North Christian Church and the [[Miller House (Columbus, Indiana)|Miller House and Garden]].<ref>{{cite web|title=May is Bike Month - City of Columbus Indiana|url=http://www.columbus.in.gov/news/may-is-bike-month/|website=www.columbus.in.gov|publisher=City of Columbus|accessdate=15 May 2016}}</ref> * The 2017 "Public Art Bike ride" featured a look at many of the public artworks around downtown.<ref>{{cite web|title=May is Bike Month - Columbus Regional Health|url=https://www.crh.org/news/2017/04/28/community-celebrates-bike-month-this-may|website=www.crh.org|accessdate=24 September 2017|language=en}}</ref>
===Landmark Lego Challenge=== In May 2016 Landmark Columbus held a first-of-its-kind competition that invited participants to build one of the seven National Historic Landmarks out of [[Lego]] bricks.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blair|first1=Brian|title=Get a leg up on LEGO building competition during opening event today|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2016/05/13/get_a_leg_up_on_lego_building_competition_during_opening_event_today/|accessdate=27 May 2016|work=The Republic}}</ref> This project was launched in partnership with the [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]], kids commons, the Columbus Indiana Architectural Archives, and other organizations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reports|first1=Staff|title=Lego challenge builds on city’s architectural foundations|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2016/05/26/lego_challenge_builds_on_citys_architectural_foundations/|accessdate=27 May 2016|work=The Republic}}</ref>
===Docomomo US Tour Day=== Various partners began participating in "Tour Day" starting in 2013 to draw regional interest in visiting Columbus and seeing the modern architecture. * In 2013, a tour was given of the Columbus Arts District and the Miller House and Gardens. <ref>{{cite web|title=TOUR DAY 2013: INDIANA {{!}} docomomo united states|url=http://www.docomomo-us.org/tour_day_2013/indiana|website=www.docomomo-us.org|accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref> * In 2014, Indiana Landmarks created the "Landmarks Experience: Columbus," a day-long immersion with lectures and tours that included the Miller House. <ref>{{cite web|title=Tour Day 2014: INDIANA {{!}} docomomo united states|url=http://www.docomomo-us.org/tour_day_2014_indiana|website=www.docomomo-us.org|accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref> * In 2015, Landmark Columbus created the "Saarinen, Pei, and the Plaza that Connected Them" tour, which looked at the relationship between the [[Cleo Rogers Memorial Library]] Henry Moore's [[Large Arch]], and First Christian Church.<ref>{{cite web|title=Saarinen, Pei, and the Plaza that Connected Them {{!}} docomomo united states|url=http://docomomo-us.org/saarinen_pei_and_plaza_connected_them|website=docomomo-us.org|accessdate=15 May 2016}}</ref>
===Documentation and surveys=== In 2013 and 14, all of the [[public art]] in [[Bartholomew County]] was surveyed, photographed, and placed in the database of the Public Art Archive.<ref>{{cite web|title=Columbus in the Public Art Archive|url=http://www.publicartarchive.org/search/apachesolr_search/?filters=im_work_coll_nid%3A69452|website=www.publicartarchive.org|accessdate=15 May 2016}}</ref> The [[list of public art in Bartholomew County, Indiana]] includes more than 100 artworks in a diverse group of places. Also at this time, all of the resources in the Columbus Arts District and all of the modern buildings were surveyed, photographed, and published in the database of CultureNOW.<ref>{{cite web|title=Columbus in CultureNOW - MuseumWithoutWalls|url=http://www.culturenow.org/map&zoom=14&latLng=39.202241,-85.922328|website=www.culturenow.org|accessdate=15 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CultureNOW - Newsletters|url=http://www.culturenow.org/newsletter&date=2014-03|website=www.culturenow.org|accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref> Other research projects have included investigations for public artworks that are now missing.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Elig|first1=Jenny|title=In search of city’s lost art|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2015/03/01/in_search_of_citys_lost_art|work=The Republic}}</ref>
===Ongoing series of talks=== Landmark Columbus occasionally hosts experts of architecture, art, and community. *2016 **Michelangelo Sabatino <ref>{{cite news|last1=Covington|first1=Olivia|title=‘Columbus is not a Museum’ topic of presentation|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2016/01/26/columbus_is_not_a_museum_topic_of_presentation-2/|work=The Republic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Columbus is not a Museum featuring Michelangelo Sabatino|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tu69SX1GTzg|website=YouTube|accessdate=14 May 2016|date=20 February 2016}}</ref> **[[ArtPrize]] and [[Exhibit Columbus]] <ref>{{cite news|last1=Staff Reports|title=Exhibit Columbus leaders bring in speaker from Grand Rapids|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2016/06/28/exhibit_columbus_leaders_bring_in_speaker_from_grand_rapids/|accessdate=23 July 2016|work=The Republic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Blair|first1=Brian|title=Exhibit Columbus has eye on the prize|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2016/07/01/exhibit_columbus_has_eye_on_the_prize/|accessdate=23 July 2016|work=The Republic}}</ref> *2018 **Sam Lubell and Greg Goldin talking about never built projects in Columbus<ref>{{cite news |last1=Blair |first1=Brian |title=Never built: Why? Program kicks off research effort in Columbus |url=http://www.therepublic.com/2018/07/01/never_built_why_program_kicks_off_research_effort_in_columbus/ |work=The Republic}}</ref>
===Public art walking tours=== With the rich history of public art throughout the community,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sims|first1=Chris|title=8 Must-See Columbus Artworks — Besides the Famed Architecture|url=http://www.limestonepostmagazine.com/8-must-see-columbus-artworks-besides-famed-architecture/|accessdate=24 November 2016|work=Limestone Post Magazine}}</ref> walking tours are frequent. There is also a special walking tour every October in partnership with Reach Healthy Communities.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reports|first1=Staff|title=Art walking tour connects residents to city, exercise|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2015/10/23/art_walking_tour_connects_residents_to_city_exercise/|accessdate=24 November 2016|work=The Republic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Reports|first1=Staff|title=Walking tour traces steps to public art|url=http://www.therepublic.com/2016/10/25/walking_tour_traces_steps_to_public_art/|accessdate=24 November 2016|work=The Republic}}</ref>
==Exhibit Columbus== [[File:2016 Announcement of Exhibit Columbus.jpg|thumb|2016 announcement event for Exhibit Columbus on the Library Plaza of the Bartholomew County Public Library]] {{main|Exhibit Columbus}} On 5 May 2016, Landmark Columbus announced Exhibit Columbus as an "annual exploration of architecture, art, design, community" that will alternate programming between symposium and exhibition years.<ref>{{cite news|title=Landmark Columbus launches ambitious program: Exhibit Columbus {{!}} docomomo united states|url=http://www.docomomo-us.org/news/landmark_columbus_launches_ambitious_program_exhibit_columbus|accessdate=23 July 2016|work=www.docomomo-us.org}}</ref> The inaugural symposium, "Foundations and Futures," took place from 29 September to 1 October, 2016. The inaugural exhibition opened in August 2017 and featured 18 temporary installations of architecture, art, and design<ref>{{cite news|last1=Grossman|first1=Dan|title=Building Columbus, and some of the country's best architecture|url=http://www.nuvo.net/indianapolis/building-columbus-and-some-of-the-countrys-best-architecture/Content?oid=4151143|accessdate=29 July 2016|work=NUVO|date=27 July 2016}}</ref> that re-energized a global dialogue around design in Columbus.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Loos |first1=Ted |title=Columbus, Ind., Renews Its Big Design Legacy |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/18/arts/design/columbus-ind-renews-its-big-design-legacy.html |accessdate=28 August 2018 |date=17 August 2017 |language=en}}</ref>,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shaw|first1=Matt|title=Columbus, Indiana announces biennial design exhibition to begin in fall 2017|url=http://archpaper.com/2016/05/columbus-indiana-announces-biennial-design-exhibition-begin-fall-2017/|accessdate=14 May 2016|work=Archpaper.com {{!}} Serving up news and inside reports to a niche community interested in the built urban environment.|date=5 May 2016|language=en-US}}</ref>

page.title: Language analysis for the determination of origin

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text:
'''Language analysis for the determination of origin''' ('''LADO''') is an instrument used in asylum cases to [[Linguistic profiling#Geographic origin|determine the national or ethnic origin]] of the asylum seeker, through an evaluation of their language profile. To this end, an interview with the asylum seeker is recorded and analysed. The analysis consists of an examination of the [[Dialectology|dialectologically]] relevant features (e.g. [[Accent (sociolinguistics)|accent]], [[grammar]], [[vocabulary]] and [[loanword]]s) in the speech of the [[asylum seeker]]. LADO is considered a type of speaker identification by [[Forensic linguistics|forensic linguists]].<ref>Peter M. Tiersma & Lawrence M. Solan (eds.), The Oxford Handbook of Language and Law. Oxford: Oxford University Press, p. 531.</ref> LADO analyses are usually made at the request of government immigration/asylum bureaux attempting to verify asylum claims, but may also be performed as part of the appeals process for claims which have been denied; they have frequently been the subject of appeals and litigation in several countries, e.g. Australia, the Netherlands and the UK.
==Background== A number of established linguistic approaches are considered to be valid methods of conducting LADO, including language variation and change,<ref>Patrick, Peter L. (2010). 'Language variation and LADO (Language Analysis for Determination of Origin).' In K Zwaan, P Muysken & M Verrips, eds., Language and Origin. The role of language in European asylum procedures: A linguistic and legal survey, pp73-87. Nijmegen: Wolf Legal Publishers.</ref><ref>JK Chambers, Peter Trudgill and Natalie Schilling-Estes, eds. (2002). The Handbook of Language Variation and Change. Oxford: Blackwell.</ref> forensic phonetics,<ref>Moosmüller, Sylvia. (2010). 'IAFPA position on language analysis in asylum procedures.' In K Zwaan, P Muysken & M Verrips, eds., Language and Origin. The Role of Language in European Asylum Procedures: A Linguistic and Legal Survey, pp. 43–47. Nijmegen: Wolf Legal Publishers.</ref> dialectology, and language assessment.<ref>McNamara, Tim & Carsten Roever. (2006). Language testing: The social dimension. Oxford: Blackwell.</ref>
The underlying assumption leading to government immigration and asylum bureaux's use of LADO is that a link exists between a person's nationality and the way they speak. To linguists, this assumption is flawed: instead, research supports links between the family and community in which a person learns their native language, and enduring features of their way of speaking it. The notion that [[Linguistic anthropology#Socialization|linguistic socialization]] into a [[speech community]] lies at the heart of LADO has been argued for by linguists since 2004,<ref>Language and National Origin Group. (2004). 'Guidelines for the Use of Language Analysis in relation to Questions of National Origin in Refugee Cases'. The International Journal of Speech, Language and the Law 11(2): 261–266.</ref> and is now accepted by a range of government agencies (e.g. Switzerland,<ref name="autogenerated9">Baltisberger, Eric & Priska Hubbuch. (2010). 'LADO with specialized linguists: The development of Lingua's working method.' In K Zwaan, P Muysken & M Verrips, eds., Language and Origin. The Role of Language in European Asylum Procedures: A Linguistic and Legal Survey, pp9-19. Nijmegen: Wolf Legal Publishers.</ref> Norway<ref>UDI 2009. 'Specified requirements for language analysis for the Norwegian Immigration Administration.' Oslo: Utlendingsdirektoratet, July 2009</ref>), academic researchers (e.g. Eades 2009,<ref>Eades, Diana. (2009). 'Testing the claims of asylum seekers: The role of language analysis.' Language Assessment Quarterly 6: 30–40.</ref> Fraser 2011,<ref>Fraser, Helen. 2011. 'Language analysis for the determination of origin (LADO).' In C. A. Chapelle (Ed.), Encyclopedia of Applied Linguistics. Wiley-Blackwell.</ref> Maryns 2006,<ref>Maryns, Katrijn. 2006. The asylum speaker: Language in the Belgian asylum procedure. Manchester: St. Jerome.</ref> and Patrick 2013<ref>Patrick, Peter L. (2013.) 'Asylum and language analysis.' In Susan K Brown & Frank D Bean (eds.), Encyclopedia of Migration. Heidelberg: Springer Verlag. http://www.springerreference.com/docs/edit/chapterdbid/349348.html</ref>), as well as some commercial agencies (e.g. De Taalstudio, according to Verrips 2010<ref>Verrips, Maaike. (2010). 'Language analysis and contra-expertise in the Dutch asylum procedure.' International Journal of Speech, Language & the Law 17(2): 279–294.</ref>).
==Where it is used== Since the mid-1990s, language analysis has been used to help determine the geographical origin of [[asylum seeker]]s by the governments of a growing number of countries (Reath, 2004),<ref>Reath, A. (2004). 'Language analysis in the context of the asylum process: Procedures, validity, and consequences.' Language Assessment Quarterly: 1–4, 209–233.</ref> now including [[Australia]], [[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Canada]], [[Finland]], [[Germany]], the [[Netherlands]], [[New Zealand]], [[Norway]], [[Sweden]], [[Switzerland]] and the [[United Kingdom]].
Pilots have been conducted by the UK, [[Ireland]], and Norway.<ref>UDI 2009. 'Specified requirements for language analysis for the Norwegian Immigration Administration.' Oslo: Utlendingsdirektoratet, July 2009. https://www.udiregelverk.no/Global/Images/Rettskilder/Rundskriv/RS%202011%20023/RS%202011%20023V5.pdf</ref> The UK legitimised the process in 2003; it has subsequently been criticised by immigration lawyers (see response by the Immigration Law Practitioners' Association<ref>IPA April 2009. 'Response to the UK Border Agency "NAM+ Asylum Programme" presentation to the National Asylum Stakeholder Forum (NASF) on 19 March 2009' http://www.docstoc.com/docs/44362029/Response-to-the-UK-Border-Agency-NAM-Asylum-Programme</ref>), and also Craig 2012<ref>Craig, Sarah. 2012. The use of language in asylum decision-making in the UK – a discussion. Journal of Immigration, Asylum and Nationality Law 26(3): 255–268. Oxford University Press: Westlaw.</ref>); and social scientists (e.g. Campbell 2013<ref>Campbell, John. (2013.) 'Language analysis in the United Kingdom's Refugee Status Determination system: Seeing through policy claims about 'expert knowledge'.' Ethnic and Racial Studies 36(4): 670–690.</ref>), as well as linguists (e.g. Patrick 2011<ref>Patrick, Peter L. (2011.) 'Key problems in language analysis for the determination of origin.' Plenary address to the International Association of Forensic Linguistics 10th Biennial conference at Aston University (July 2011). http://privatewww.essex.ac.uk/~patrickp/papers/IAFL10plenary_July2011.pdf</ref>).
In the [[Netherlands]] LADO is commissioned by the Dutch Immigration Service (IND, http://www.ind.nl/Themas/Taalanalyse/Pages/default.aspx). Language analysis is used by the IND in cases where asylum seekers cannot produce valid identification documents, and, in addition, the IND sees reason to doubt the claimed origin of the asylum seeker. The IND has a specialised unit (Bureau Land en Taal, or BLT; in English, the Office for Country Information and Language Analysis, or OCILA) that carries out these analyses. Challenges to BLT analyses are provided by De Taalstudio <http://www.taalstudio.nl/taalanalyse/index_uk.html>, a private company that provides language analysis and contra-expertise in LADO cases. Claims and criticisms regarding the Dutch LADO processes are discussed by Cambier-Langeveld (2010),<ref>Cambier-Langeveld, T. (2010.) 'The validity of language analysis in the Netherlands.' In K Zwaan, P Muysken & M Verrips, eds., Language and Origin. The Role of Language in European Asylum Procedures: A Linguistic and Legal Survey, pp. 21–33. Nijmegen: Wolf Legal Publishers.</ref> the senior linguist for BLT/OCILA, and by Verrips 2010,<ref>Verrips, Maaike. (2010.) 'Language analysis and contra-expertise in the Dutch asylum procedure.' International Journal of Speech, Language & the Law 17(2): 279–294.</ref> the founder of De Taalstudio. Zwaan (2008,<ref>Zwaan, Karin (ed). (2008). De taalanalyse in de Nederlandse asielprocedure. Een juridische en linguïstische verkenning. Nijmegen: Wolf Legal Publishers.</ref> 2010<ref>Zwaan, Karin. (2010.) 'Dutch court decisions and language analysis for the determination of origin.' In K Zwaan, P Muysken & M Verrips, eds., Language and Origin. The Role of Language in European Asylum Procedures: A Linguistic and Legal Survey, pp. 43–47. Nijmegen: Wolf Legal Publishers.</ref>) reviews the legal situation.
LADO reports are provided to governments in a number of ways: by their own regularly-employed linguists and/or freelance analysts; by independent academic experts; by commercial firms; or by a mixture of the above. In Switzerland language analysis is carried out by LINGUA, a specialized unit of the Federal Office for Migration, which both employs linguists and retains independent experts from around the world.<ref name="autogenerated9"/> The German and Austrian bureaux commission reports primarily from experts within their own countries. The UK and a number of other countries have commercial contracts with providers such as the Swedish firms Sprakab<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sprakab.se/Home.html |title=Home |publisher=Sprakab.se |date= |accessdate=2013-10-07}}</ref> and Verified <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.verified.se/ |title=Verified AB – Language Analyses, Dialect Identification, Linguistic Expertise |publisher=Verified.se |date= |accessdate=2013-10-07}}</ref> both of which have carried out language analyses for UK Visas and Immigration (formerly UK Border Agency) and for the Dutch Immigration Service, as well as other countries around the world.
==Language analysts== It is widely agreed that language analysis should be done by language experts. Two basic types of practitioners commonly involved in LADO can be distinguished: trained native speakers of the language under analysis, and professional linguists specialized in the language under analysis. Usually native speaker analysts are free-lance employees who are said to be under the supervision of a qualified linguist. When such analysts lack academic training in linguistics, it has been questioned whether they should be accorded the status of 'experts' by asylum tribunals, e.g. by Patrick (2012),<ref>Patrick, Peter L. (2012.) 'Language analysis for determination of origin: Objective evidence for refugee status determination.' Chapter 38 in Peter M. Tiersma & Lawrence M. Solan (eds.), The Oxford Handbook of Language and Law. Oxford: Oxford University Press, p. 544</ref> who refers to them instead as "non-expert native speakers (NENSs)". Eades et al. (2003) note that "people who have studied linguistics to professional levels [...] have particular knowledge which is not available to either ordinary speakers or specialists in other disciplines".<ref>Eades, D., H. Fraser, J. Siegel, T. McNamara & B. Baker. (2003.) 'Linguistic identification in the determination of nationality: A preliminary report.' Language Policy 2: 179–199.</ref> Likewise Dikker and Verrips (2004)<ref>Dikker, S. & Verrips, M. (2004.) 'Taalanalyse: een vak apart.' Onderzoeksrapport. Monnickendam: De Taalstudio.</ref> conclude that native speakers who lack training in linguistics are not able to formulate reliable conclusions regarding the origin of other speakers of their language. The nature of the training which commercial firms and government bureaux provide to their analysts has been questioned in academic and legal arenas, but few specifics have been provided to date; see however accounts by the Swiss agency Lingua<ref>Baltisberger, Eric & Priska Hubbuch. (2010.) 'LADO with specialized linguists: The development of Lingua's working method.' In K Zwaan, P Muysken & M Verrips, eds., Language and Origin. The Role of Language in European Asylum Procedures: A Linguistic and Legal Survey, pp9-19. Nijmegen: Wolf Legal Publishers.</ref> and Cambier-Langeveld of BLT/OCILA,<ref>Cambier-Langeveld, T. (2010.) 'The role of linguists and native speakers in language analysis for the determination of speaker origin.' International Journal of Speech, Language & the Law 17(1): 67–93</ref> as well as responses to the latter by Fraser <ref>Fraser, Helen. (2011.) 'The role of linguists and native speakers in language analysis for the determination of speaker origin: A response to Tina Cambier-Langeveld.' International Journal of Speech, Language & the Law 18(1): 121–130.</ref> and Verrips.<ref>Verrips, Maaike. (2011.) 'LADO and the pressure to draw strong conclusions: A response to Tina Cambier-Langeveld.' International Journal of Speech, Language & the Law 18(1): 131–143.</ref>
Claims for and against the use of such native-speaker analysts, and their ability to conduct LADO satisfactorily vis-a-vis the ability of academically-trained linguists, have only recently begun to be the subject of research (e.g. Wilson 2009),<ref>Wilson, Kim. (2009.) 'Language analysis for the determination of origin: Native speakers vs. trained linguists.' MSc dissertation in Linguistics, University of York</ref> and no consensus yet exists among linguists. While much linguistic research exists on the ability of people, including trained linguists and phoneticians and untrained native speakers, to correctly perceive, identify or label recorded speech that is played to them, almost none of the research has yet been framed in such a way that it can give clear answers to questions about the LADO context.
==Litigation== The matter of native-speaker analysts and many other issues are subjects of ongoing litigation in asylum tribunals and appeals courts in several countries. Vedsted Hansen (2010<ref>Vedsted Hansen, Jens. 2010. 'The use of language analysis in the Danish asylum procedure.' In K Zwaan, P Muysken & M Verrips, eds., Language and Origin. The Role of Language in European Asylum Procedures: A Linguistic and Legal Survey, pp. 199–207. Nijmegen: Wolf Legal Publishers.</ref>) describes the Danish situation, Noll (2010<ref>Noll, Gregor. 2010. 'The 2007 rejection of anonymous language analysis by the Swedish Migration Court of Appeal: A precedent?' In K Zwaan, P Muysken & M Verrips, eds., Language and Origin. The Role of Language in European Asylum Procedures: A Linguistic and Legal Survey, pp. 211–213. Nijmegen: Wolf Legal Publishers.</ref>) comments on Sweden, and Zwaan (2010) reviews the Dutch situation.
In the UK, a 2010 Upper Tribunal (asylum) case known as 'RB',<ref>RB (Linguistic evidence Sprakab) Somalia [2010] UKUT 329 (IAC) (15 September 2010), http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKUT/IAC/2010/00329_ukut_iac_2010_rb_somalia.html</ref> supported by a 2012 Court of Appeal decision,<ref>RB (Somalia) v Secretary of State for the Home Department [2012] EWCA Civ 277 (13 March 2012), http://www.bailii.org/cgi-bin/markup.cgi?doc=/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2012/277.html&query=rb+and+somalia&method=boolean</ref> argue for giving considerable weight to LADO reports carried out by the methodology of native-speaker analyst plus supervising linguist. In contrast, a 2013 Scottish Court of Sessions decision known as M.Ab.N+K.A.S.Y.<ref>M.Ab.N. & K.A.S.Y. v SSHD [2013] CSIH 68, http://www.scotcourts.gov.uk/opinions/2013CSIH68.html</ref> found that all such reports must be weighed against the standard Practice Directions for expert reports. Lawyers in the latter case have argued that "What matters is the lack of qualification",<ref>Bryce, Joseph. Free Movement blog, 24 July 2013. 'Court of Sessions rules on linguistic analysis.' http://www.freemovement.org.uk/2013/07/24/court-of-session-rules-on-linguistic-analysis/</ref> and since the Scottish court has equal standing to the England and Wales Appeals Court, the UK Supreme Court was petitioned to address the issues. On 5–6 March 2014, the UK Supreme Court <ref>UK Supreme Court. http://www.supremecourt.uk/</ref> heard an appeal<ref>UKSC 2012/0202. {{cite web |url=http://www.supremecourt.uk/cases/case_2013_0202.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407082701/http://www.supremecourt.uk/cases/case_2013_0202.html |archivedate=2014-04-07 |df= }}</ref> brought by the Home Office concerning the nature of expert linguistic evidence provided to the Home Office in asylum cases, whether expert witness should be granted anonymity, the weight that should be given to reports by the Swedish firm Sprakab, and related matters.
==Criticism== Some methods of language analysis in asylum procedures have been heavily criticized by many linguists (e.g., Eades et al. 2003;<ref>Eades, Diana & Jacques Arends, eds. (2004). Language Analysis and Determination of Nationality. In International Journal of Speech, Language & the Law: Forensic Linguistics, 11(2): 179–266.</ref> Arends, 2003). Proponents of the use of native-speaker analysts agree that "[earlier] LADO reports were not very satisfactory from a linguistic point of view... [while even] today's reports are still not likely to satisfy the average academic linguist".<ref>Cambier-Langeveld, T. (2012.) 'Clarification of the issues in language analysis: A rejoinder to Fraser and Verrips.' International Journal of Speech, Language & the Law 19(1): 95, 108, p. 104.</ref> Following an item on the Dutch public radio programme Argos, member of parliament De Wit of the Socialist Party presented a number of questions to the State Secretary of the Ministry of Justice regarding the reliability of LADO. The questions and the responses by the State Secretary can be found here.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justitie.nl/images/betrouwbaarheid%20taalanalyses_12840_tcm34-161304.pdf |title=Ministerie van Veiligheid en Justitie | Rijksoverheid.nl |publisher=Justitie.nl |date=1995-04-30 |accessdate=2013-10-07}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Shibboleth]] *[[Linguistic profiling]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Fraser, Helen. (2011.) 'Language analysis for the determination of origin (LADO).' In C. A. Chapelle (Ed.), Encyclopedia of Applied Linguistics. Wiley-Blackwell.
* Language and National Origin Group. (2004.) 'Guidelines for the use of language analysis in relation to questions of national origin in refugee cases.' International Journal of Speech, Language & the Law 11(2): 261–66. Available at UNHCR RefWorld http://www.refworld.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/rwmain?page=search&docid=4cbebc852&skip=0&query=language%20analysis
* Patrick, Peter L. (2012) 'Language analysis for determination of origin: Objective evidence for refugee status determination.' Chapter 38 in Peter M. Tiersma & Lawrence M. Solan (eds.), The Oxford Handbook of Language and Law. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 533–546.
